Day 5 – Hackathon Hustle

-- Find a fit

Let’s talk about writing SQL queries that don’t just get the job done, but run smoothly and efficiently. 

Here are a few quick tips to improve your queries:

1️⃣ 𝗨𝘀𝗲 𝗖𝗧𝗘𝘀 & 𝗞𝗲𝗲𝗽 𝗶𝘁 𝗰𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿
Skip the complicated nested subqueries. Try using Common Table Expressions (CTEs) instead—they make your code cleaner and easier to follow.

2️⃣ 𝗨𝘀𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗽𝗲𝗿 𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗮 𝘁𝘆𝗽𝗲𝘀
Make sure you’re using the right data types for your columns. For example, if you’re storing numbers, don’t use a text field. This simple step can improve performance and save space.

3️⃣ 𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗲𝗰𝘁 𝗼𝗻𝗹𝘆 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱
Avoid "SELECT *" and grab only the columns you actually need. It keeps things faster and easier to maintain.

4️⃣ 𝐅𝐢𝐥𝐭𝐞𝐫 𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐥𝐲
Use your WHERE clause to narrow down data early in the query. The smaller the dataset, the faster the result.

5️⃣ 𝐒𝐦𝐚𝐫𝐭 𝐣𝐨𝐢𝐧𝐬
Joins can get heavy, so always consider the size of the tables. Joining smaller datasets first can help keep things running quickly.

That’s it! Efficient SQL takes practice, but these tips should help you optimize your queries.

This Resume got me interviews at 
JPMorganChase, Roblox, Snap Inc., Barclays and more!

Here’s how you can land them too:

"Please review my resume" - the most used phrase on LinkedIn

With the right resume, you can open doors to some amazing opportunities.

Here’s exactly how you should structure a solid resume:

1. Education:
-- Let the hiring manager know the foundation you’ve built.
-- GPA is optional (unless they specifically ask).
-- Use this section to add relevant coursework that boosts keyword visibility.

2. Work Experience:
-- Don’t just list tasks (show how you solved problems).
-- Back it up with results. Use numbers to build credibility.
 – Highlight cross-functional work or team impact where possible.

3. Skills:
-- Highlight the skills you’re confident in applying on Day 1.
-- Focus on a blend of technical and soft skills.
-- This is your keyword goldmine (optimize it smartly).

4. Projects:
-- Great for showcasing hands-on expertise, especially if you're pivoting industries or roles.
-- Projects are your playground (use them to tell your story and interests).
-- Bonus tip: Include links (if public) so they can explore your work.

5. Make it Yours:
-- Templates are fine, but your journey is not a template.
-- Don’t copy-paste others' resumes (personalize your narrative).
-- Let your uniqueness come through subtly but clearly.

Bonus Resume Tips:
-- Stick to 1 page if you have under 8-10 years of experience.
-- Use quantifiable results: “Improved X by Y% through Z.”
-- Avoid jargon, but tailor your language to the job description.
-- Create slightly tweaked versions for different roles (yes, it’s worth the effort).
-- Keep design clean and ATS-friendly (no fancy graphics, no tables).

If you’ve been applying and hearing nothing back, don’t lose hope.

Give these changes a shot for just a couple of weeks, it might be the breakthrough you need.

I know the job search can feel overwhelming and lonely at times, but remember: you’re not alone in this.

You’re doing your best, and that counts for something.

SQL Cheat Sheet (Super Short Version)

1. Basics

🔹️SELECT column1, column2 FROM table; → Retrieve data

🔹️SELECT * FROM table; → Retrieve all columns

🔹️DISTINCT → Remove duplicates

🔹️ORDER BY column ASC/DESC; → Sort results

🔹️LIMIT n; → Restrict number of results


2. Filtering

🔸️WHERE column = 'value'; → Filter data

🔸️AND, OR, NOT → Combine conditions

🔸️IN (value1, value2) → Match multiple values

🔸️BETWEEN value1 AND value2 → Range filter

🔸️LIKE 'pattern%' → Pattern matching

🔸️IS NULL / IS NOT NULL → Handle null values


3. Aggregation

🔹️COUNT(*), SUM(column), AVG(column), MIN(column), MAX(column)

🔹️GROUP BY column; → Group data

🔹️HAVING condition; → Filter after aggregation


4. Joins

🔸️INNER JOIN → Matching rows in both tables

🔸️LEFT JOIN → All rows from left + matching right

🔸️RIGHT JOIN → All rows from right + matching left


5. Modifying Data

🔹️INSERT INTO table VALUES (...);

🔹️UPDATE table SET column = value WHERE condition;

🔹️DELETE FROM table WHERE condition;


6. Creating Tables

🔸️CREATE TABLE table_name (column1 TYPE, column2 TYPE);

🔸️DROP TABLE table_name;

3. 𝐇𝐞𝐚𝐥𝐭𝐡𝐜𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐰𝐢𝐥𝐥 𝐬𝐡𝐨𝐜𝐤 𝐲𝐨𝐮.

 There will be nights when you miss home so much it hurts, or days when nothing seems to go as planned. But remember, staying connected with family and friends will be your lifeline. You’re never truly alone.

Because it’s worth it. Your struggles will transform into growth, your sacrifices into successes. And one day, when you look at your first paycheck or feel the sense of belonging, you’ll know—you made it. One day, you’ll feel like YOU ARE HOME!
